title: Arjen Robben says mood at Bayern Munich hasn't changed despite Pep Guardiola's exit
title_page: Arjen Robben says mood at Bayern Munich hasn't changed despite Pep Guardiola's exit | Daily Mail Online
text:
Bayern are currently on their winter break and next play on January 22
Pep Guardiola announced that he will leave the club in the summer
Arjen Robben insists it is business as usual in the Bayern Munich camp, despite Pep Guardiola having announced that this will be his final season with the German giants.
Guardiola revealed that he wants to manage in the Barclays Premier League and the 44-year-old Spaniard is likely to end up at Manchester City this summer.
Robben took part in a training session in Doha on Sunday and, despite being sad to see him go, said the mood had not been affected by Guardiola's decision to leave.
Arjen Robben (centre) insists the departure of Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola (right)
Guardiola (pictured on Sunday) revealed that he wants to manage in the Premier League next season
'It is very sad that he will not continue,' Robben said. 'I would like to work with him over a longer period. We learned a lot from him and he is improving each player.
'But it is not over yet. We have around six months to go and we have to enjoy this time with him and try to be successful.'
Asked if the mood behind the scenes had changed, Robben answered sarcastically: 'Yeah, it is totally different. He is not fully committed any more.
'No, it is not different. I think we have too much experience. In this business it is usual. Players come and go and that goes for coaches as well. We have to continue our work.
'We just have one goal and that goal is to be successful. We have to focus on that.'
Robben (pictured signing autographs in Doha on Sunday) took part in a first-team training session
Robben insists the mood had not been affected by Guardiola's decision to leave at the end of this season
His Bayern team-mate Jerome Boateng felt the same and added: 'When I was younger I also wanted to go to England. That's different for every player.
'Some just want to stay in the same country all the time. I think you have to respect that and it's totally understandable.
